ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:0.2_0: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:0.5_0: 12. The training rule on light cloaks
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.2_0: At that time Thullanandā was a learned reciter, and she was confident and skilled at giving teachings.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.3_0: On one occasion when the weather was warm, king Pasenadi of Kosala dressed in an expensive linen cloak and went to Thullanandā.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.3_1: bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.4_0: The nun Thullanandā instructed, inspired, and gladdened her with a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.5_0: The king then said to the nun Thullanandā,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.7_0: “Great king, if you wish to give me something, then give me this linen cloak.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.8_0: The king gave her his cloak. He then got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated her with his right side toward her, and left.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.9_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.10_0: “They have great desires; they’re not content.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.11_0: How can they ask the king for his linen cloak?”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.12_0: Nuns heard the complaints of those people,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.13_0: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized Thullanandā,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.14_0: “How could Venerable Thullanandā ask the king for his linen cloak?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.15_0: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā asked for this?”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.18_0: “... How could the nun Thullanandā ask the king for his linen cloak?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.19_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.20_0: the Buddha said, “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.21.1_0: ‘If a nun carries out an exchange to get a light cloak, it is to be worth at most two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:1.21.1_1: If he exchanges something beyond that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.2_0: whatever cloak is used in warm weather.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.5_0: It is to be worth at most two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.6_0: it may be worth ten _kahāpaṇa_ coins.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.7_0: If he exchanges something beyond that:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.8_0: if he asks for more than that, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.9_0: When he gets the sitting-blanket, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.10_0: It should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.11_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.13_0: ‘Venerables, this light cloak worth more than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, which I got in exchange, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.15_0: Suppose that they were to give?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.16_0: Please give her back to you.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.17.1_0: If it is worth more than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, and she perceives it as such, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.18_0: If it is worth more than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, but she is unsure of it, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.19_0: If it is worth more than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, but she perceives it as worth less, and she gets it in exchange, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.20_0: If it is worth less than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, but she perceives it as worth more, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.21_0: If it is worth less than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, but she is unsure of it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.1.22_0: If it is worth less than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins, and she perceives it as such, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.2_0: if she carries out an exchange for one worth at most two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.3_0: if she carries out an exchange for one worth less than two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.5_0: if he asks those who have given an invitation;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.6_0: if he asks for the benefit of someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.7_0: if it is by means of one’s own property;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.8_0: if the lay person wishes to buy something expensive, but the monk gets them to buy something inexpensive;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.10_0: if she is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.11_0: The twelfth rule, the training rule on twelfthing, is finished.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.14_0: “Venerables, the thirty rules on relinquishment and confession have been recited.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.17_0: A second time I ask the Sangha to answer:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.21_0: This is the meaning of, I will remember it. I will remember it thus.’
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-np12:2.2.22_0: The chapter on offenses entailing relinquishment in the nuns’ analysis is finished.
